channel.title: Stop melting coins Americans! It's Illegal now
channel.description:
[url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/14/business/14pennies.html?ref=business]From here[/url]
A number of people have noted the action by the U.S. Mint to outlaw the melting down or bulk export of coins. This has come about because the value of the precious metals contained in coins now exceeds their face value. The Mint would rather not have to replace pennies (at a cost of 1.73 cents per) or nickels (at 8.74 cents). The expectation is that Congress will mandate new compositions for some U.S. coins in 2007.
Wow the metals in the coins are worth more then the coins themselves.

item.title: Stop melting coins Americans! It's Illegal now
item.dc:creator: @jcs_double jcs_double
item.description:
@jcs_double wrote:

Yz85Racer:

I’m not sure if it’s illegal in Australia though, if not, WHOO. If it is, DAMN.

im pretty sure its not illegal i once had a $2 coin that was bent in half, i acadentally ripped a $20 note in half they were both accepted and ive carved to many things into coins

Read full topic

item.title: Stop melting coins Americans! It's Illegal now
item.dc:creator: @goatee goatee
item.description:
@goatee wrote:

[quote=“The Un-Named, post:5, topic:35523”]I quote: The Mint is also testing dozens of cheaper alternative metal.

Also, for those who live in the UK, a 1P coin is worth 2P in metal.[/quote]

Read full topic
item.source: Stop melting coins Americans! It's Illegal now

item.title: Stop melting coins Americans! It's Illegal now
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

Cheatest:

your an idiot plastic melts with low temperature heat… and money is supposed to be what its worth not have a quarter worth 25 cents and have a half a cent piece of plastic replace it, do i hear counterfeits all around with that idea??

Don’t try to sound smart. Money is based on either metallic backing in the national reserves, or in the US’s case, trust in the government.
Not all plastic melts at low temperatures. Polyetheretherketones have a melting point of 350 C, 650 F. Unless you are going to be carrying cash in an oven, I’m pretty sure you don’t have to worry about melting.
Metal can be just as easily counterfeited as plastic.
Think before you post.

Read full topic
item.source: Stop melting coins Americans! It's Illegal now

item.title: Stop melting coins Americans! It's Illegal now
item.dc:creator: @Cheatest Cheatest
item.description:
@Cheatest wrote:

cruel:

[quote author=BloodRayne link=topic=50869.msg625083#msg625083 date=1166231205]I find it quite retarded that the coins cost more money to make, then what there worth… I mean, who’s stupid enough??

Oh? And what do you propose, genius?
It’s not exactly easy to make durable and inviolable coin for less than 1 cent.
It’d be quite difficult to stop the production/circulation of pennies as well.

BTW, I thought it was already illegal to deface currency?
:/[/quote]
it is illegal to ruin money l0l.

Read full topic
